topic: Perfect Tenses: Present Perfect, Past Perfect, Future Perfect
detailedSummary: Perfect tenses combine 'haber' (to have) with past participles to express completed actions relative to different time frames. Present perfect (pretérito perfecto): 'He comido' (I have eaten) - actions completed recently or with present relevance. Formation: present of 'haber' (he, has, ha, hemos, habéis, han) + past participle. Past participles: -ar verbs → -ado (hablado), -er/-ir verbs → -ido (comido, vivido). Irregular participles: abrir → abierto, escribir → escrito, hacer → hecho, ver → visto, volver → vuelto. Past perfect (pluscuamperfecto): 'Había comido' (I had eaten) - actions completed before another past action. Formation: imperfect of 'haber' (había, habías, había, habíamos, habíais, habían) + past participle. Future perfect: 'Habré comido' (I will have eaten) - actions that will be completed by a future time. Formation: future of 'haber' (habré, habrás, habrá, habremos, habréis, habrán) + past participle. Conditional perfect: 'Habría comido' (I would have eaten). Uses: present perfect for recent past, past perfect for 'had done', future perfect for 'will have done'. Mastering perfect tenses enables precise time expression.
whyItMatters: Perfect tenses are essential for expressing completed actions relative to different time frames - they're used constantly in conversation and are crucial for advanced Spanish communication.

assignments.title: Master Perfect Tenses
assignments.description: Practice using all perfect tenses to express completed actions in different time contexts.
tasks: Conjugate 'haber' in present, imperfect, and future tenses
Form past participles for regular and irregular verbs
Write sentences using present perfect for recent actions
Use past perfect to show actions completed before other past actions
Practice future perfect to express actions that will be completed by future times

quizzes.question: What is the present perfect form of 'comer' for 'yo'?
quizzes.explanation: 'He comido' is present perfect (I have eaten) - formed with present of 'haber' (he) + past participle (comido).

quizzes.question: Past participles ending in '-ado' are for -ar verbs, while '-ido' is for -er and -ir verbs.
quizzes.explanation: True. Regular past participles: -ar verbs → -ado (hablado), -er/-ir verbs → -ido (comido, vivido).

quizzes.question: What does 'había comido' mean?
quizzes.explanation: 'Había comido' is past perfect (I had eaten) - an action completed before another past action.
